episodes.title: Interview with Sarah McCammon, author of "The Exvangelicals"
episodes.description:
Sarah McCammon is a National Political Correspondent for NPR and cohost of The NPR Politics Podcast. Her new book is called "The Exvangelicals: Loving, Living, and Leaving the White Evangelical Church."

Affiliate link here: https://bit.ly/43N0y1W

Growing up in a deeply evangelical family in the Midwest in the ‘80s and ‘90s, Sarah McCammon was strictly taught to fear God, obey him, and not question the faith. Persistently worried that her gay grandfather would go to hell unless she could reach him, or that her Muslim friend would need to be converted, and that she, too, would go to hell if she did not believe fervently enough, McCammon was a rule-follower and—most of the time—a true believer. But through it all, she was increasingly plagued by fears and deep questions as the belief system she'd been carefully taught clashed with her expanding understanding of the outside world.

After spending her early adult life striving to make sense of an unraveling worldview, by her 30s, she found herself face-to-face with it once again as she covered the Trump campaign for NPR, where she witnessed first-hand the power and influence that evangelical Christian beliefs held on the political right.

Sarah also came to discover that she was not alone: she is among a rising generation of the children of evangelicalism who are growing up and fleeing the fold, who are thinking for themselves and deconstructing what feel like the “alternative facts” of their childhood.

Rigorously reported and deeply personal, The Exvangelicals is the story of the people who make up this generational tipping point, including Sarah herself. Part memoir, part investigative journalism, this is the first definitive book that names and describes the post-evangelical movement: identifying its origins, telling the stories of its members, and examining its vast cultural, social, and political impact.

episodes.title: Interview with Jess Piper about the "Fundie Baby Voice"
episodes.description:
After Senator Katie Britt's response to the State of the Union went viral for all the wrong reasons, Jess Piper wrote about how her voice was all too familiar. It had all the hallmarks of a "well-practiced fundie baby voice."

That voice, famously used by Michelle Duggar and so many others, is a phenomenon worth exploring, and there's no one better than Jess to speak to about it. 

You can read Jess' article here: https://jesspiper.substack.com/p/the-fundie-baby-voice

episodes.title: Norwegian court upholds ban on state funding for Jehovah's Witnesses (Livestream)
episodes.description:
A Norwegian court upheld a decision to rescind the "religious community" status of the Jehovah's Witnesses, a move that blocks the JWs from receiving taxpayer-funded subsidies and performing legal marriages. 

It was the group's cult-like behavior that led to their punishment.

episodes.title: A chat with Andrew Pledger, host of "Surviving Bob Jones University: A Christian Cult"
episodes.description:
Andrew Pledger is a former student at Bob Jones University, a fundamentalist Christian school with a long and not-so-great history. He's also the host of a new podcast called Surviving Bob Jones University: A Christian Cult." 

The stories in that podcast are depressing as all hell but they're so important to hear if you want to get a real sense of what schools like these do to people.

You can listen to the podcast here: https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/surviving-bob-jones-university-a-christian-cult/id1681943920
